| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            | [SLASH'EM\_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line205](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line205 "SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c") |

A **black wasp**, a, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). It has a single sting attack that can [poison](/wiki/Poison "Poison") its victim.

Eating a black wasp [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 3⁄5 chance of conveying [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopaedia entry](#Encyclopaedia_entry)

## Generation

Black wasps always generate hostile and may appear in large [groups](/wiki/Group "Group").

## Strategy

Black wasps are fast and can deal decent damage with their sting, giving black wasp swarms the ability to overwhelm an unprepared character. Most players entering the midgame should already have poison resistance and various means of dealing with large groups: an [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") engraved in dust can be enough to scatter the wasps, making it easier to isolate and kill them. Black wasps share the same glyph as the weaker [yellow jacket](/wiki/Yellow_jacket "Yellow jacket") or [killer bee](/wiki/Killer_bee "Killer bee") - be sure to [far look](/wiki/Far_look "Far look") any a you see via [:](/wiki/Colon "Colon") (particularly if you have [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy")) so that you are not caught off guard.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Hymenoptera](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hymenoptera "wikipedia:Hymenoptera")***

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Sphex pensylvanicus](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphex_pensylvanicus "wikipedia:Sphex pensylvanicus")***

*Hymenoptera* is a large order of insects comprising the various types of wasps, as well as bees, sawflies and ants. The great black wasp (*Sphex pensylvanicus*) is a species of [digger wasp](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digger_wasp "wikipedia:Digger wasp") that lives across most of North America and grows to a size of 20–35 mm (0.8–1.4 in); the males of the species are smaller than females on average.

Like most digger wasps, adult females use their stingers to inject paralyzing venom into prey such as katydids and grasshoppers, then carry the still-living prey to their underground nest - eggs are laid on the prey insects (rather than inside as stated by the encyclopedia entry), providing a food source for the wasp larvae when they eventually hatch.

## Encyclopaedia entry

This encyclopedia entry only appears in Hack'EM:

These insects are feared for their ability to lay eggs inside  
the bodies of their prey.

[![This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.](/images/3/38/Se7e7-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.")

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

Black wasp

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
a black wasp
Difficulty 12
Attacks Sting 2d6 poison
a black wasp
Difficulty 12
Attacks

Sting 2d6 poison

Base level 9
Base experience 206
Speed 15
Base AC 2
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 300
Nutritional value 100
Size Medium
Resistances poison
Resistances conveyed poison (60%)

A black wasp:

  • can fly.
  • has no hands.
  • is an animal.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • does not appear in Gehennom.
  • normally appears in large groups.
Reference SLASH'EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line205

A black wasp, a, is a type of monster that appears in SLASH'EM, SlashTHEM and Hack'EM. It has a single sting attack that can poison its victim.

Eating a black wasp corpse or tin has a 3⁄5 chance of conveying poison resistance.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopaedia entry

Generation

Black wasps always generate hostile and may appear in large groups.

Strategy

Black wasps are fast and can deal decent damage with their sting, giving black wasp swarms the ability to overwhelm an unprepared character. Most players entering the midgame should already have poison resistance and various means of dealing with large groups: an Elbereth engraved in dust can be enough to scatter the wasps, making it easier to isolate and kill them. Black wasps share the same glyph as the weaker yellow jacket or killer bee - be sure to far look any a you see via : (particularly if you have telepathy) so that you are not caught off guard.

Origin

Hymenoptera
Wikipedia has an article about:
Sphex pensylvanicus

Hymenoptera is a large order of insects comprising the various types of wasps, as well as bees, sawflies and ants. The great black wasp (Sphex pensylvanicus) is a species of digger wasp that lives across most of North America and grows to a size of 20–35 mm (0.8–1.4 in); the males of the species are smaller than females on average.

Like most digger wasps, adult females use their stingers to inject paralyzing venom into prey such as katydids and grasshoppers, then carry the still-living prey to their underground nest - eggs are laid on the prey insects (rather than inside as stated by the encyclopedia entry), providing a food source for the wasp larvae when they eventually hatch.

A '''black wasp''', {{monsym|black wasp}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[SLASH'EM]], [[SlashTHEM]] and [[Hack'EM]]. It has a single sting attack that can [[poison]] its victim.

Eating a black wasp [[corpse]] or [[tin]] has a {{frac|3|5}} chance of conveying [[poison resistance]].

==Generation==
Black wasps always generate hostile and may appear in large [[group]]s.

==Strategy==
Black wasps are fast and can deal decent damage with their sting, giving black wasp swarms the ability to overwhelm an unprepared character. Most players entering the midgame should already have poison resistance and various means of dealing with large groups: an [[Elbereth]] engraved in dust can be enough to scatter the wasps, making it easier to isolate and kill them. Black wasps share the same glyph as the weaker [[yellow jacket]] or [[killer bee]] - be sure to [[far look]] any {{yellow|a}} you see via {{kbd|:}} (particularly if you have [[telepathy]]) so that you are not caught off guard.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Hymenoptera}}
{{wikipedia|Sphex pensylvanicus}}
''Hymenoptera'' is a large order of insects comprising the various types of wasps, as well as bees, sawflies and ants. The great black wasp (''Sphex pensylvanicus'') is a species of [[Wikipedia:Digger wasp|digger wasp]] that lives across most of North America and grows to a size of 20–35 mm (0.8–1.4 in); the males of the species are smaller than females on average.

Like most digger wasps, adult females use their stingers to inject paralyzing venom into prey such as katydids and grasshoppers, then carry the still-living prey to their underground nest - eggs are laid on the prey insects (rather than inside as stated by the encyclopedia entry), providing a food source for the wasp larvae when they eventually hatch.
